Award.AwardTitle: Examining an Innovative Approach to Supporting Science Teachers Practice towards Three-Dimensional Learning Goals through Adapting Classroom Assessment Tasks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. This collaborative project will conduct early stage research on promising advances in how we prepare science teachers to support three-dimensional science learning as outlined in the Framework for Science Education (National Research Council, 2012). In order to achieve the new goals for science teaching and learning aimed for in current standards reforms, there is a need for radically new models of professional development of science teachers. While prior research has identified that 80-100 hours of professional development is necessary for teachers to change their instructional vision and practice to align with the Next Generation Science Standards, most states and districts who are adopting the new standards do not have the resources to support teacher preparation to this extent. This project aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of a new approach to designing support tools and professional development focused on adapting classroom assessments that achieves these shifts in teachers' instructional vision and practice in less than 20 hours of professional development. The team will also discern the contributions to changes in teachers' instructional vision when teachers only use the support tools versus using the tools in the context of the full professional development model. Evidence of effectiveness of this high leverage approach to teacher preparation focused on adapting classroom assessments is important in order to develop scalable solutions to the significant science teacher professional development need created by the recent adoption of the Next Generation Science Standards by 28 states and numerous other districts.

The project will conduct a two-iteration comparative research study that explores differences in outcomes between science teachers who use only the support tools as resources to adapt classroom tasks versus those who use the tools as part of a two-day professional development experience. The outcomes include changes in teachers' instructional vision related to three-dimensional science learning as measured by a teacher vision survey and teacher interviews, and improvements in the quality of teachers' adapted assessment tasks as determined by a rubric-based analysis and observations of the professional development sessions. Data analysis will follow a conjecture-mapping strategy to compare changes over time within and across groups in order to evaluate hypothesized links between design features of the tools and professional development models, mediating processes, and outcomes. Findings of this study will provide evidence to inform instructional leaders and designs for science teacher preparation, and lead to future development and research in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Building Capacity to Analyze and Adapt Tasks Focused on 3-Dimensional Learning Goals” project developed a novel approach to supporting teachers’ professional learning about science assessment that is aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and the National Research Council’s Framework for K-12 Science Education (NRC, 2012). This approach involves the development of tools and resources that teachers can use to improve the quality of their assessment tasks, as well as structured learning experiences that are relatively brief in nature (approximately 20 hours) but highly focused in scope. All of the professional learning supports developed by the project are intended as “targeted scaffolds” that can improve teachers’ capacity to design high-quality assessments of their students’ 3D science learning.


The project conducted two “micro-cycles” of design and revision to iterate on the tools and learning experiences and investigate the feasibility and potential effectiveness of this approach to professional learning. Each cycle involved two groups of teachers: one group took part in face-to-face workshops and the other group received a set of tools for their own individual use without participating in any workshops. 


Between the first and second design studies, the learning experiences and tools were revised to take into account teachers’ feedback. The learning experiences were reframed to more explicitly support teachers’ understanding of the NGSS, including a more nuanced exploration at what three-dimensional assessments that align to the NGSS look like. The tools were refined to provide more targeted assessment design supports in areas that proved challenging for teachers.


In total, 25 high school science teachers participated in the study. Data collection included pre and post-assessment tasks generated by the teachers, interviews to capture the teachers’ experiences and views of science instruction, and field notes from the professional development workshops. 


Key findings involved the effectiveness of the approach to professional learning, including a comparison of teachers who participated in the face-to-face workshops and those who only received tools for individual study. The project developed a rubric to measure the quality of the assessment tasks written by the teachers. High quality tasks are three dimensional (i.e., they created opportunities for students to use targeted disciplinary core ideas, science and engineering practices, and cross-cutting concepts), scenario-based (i.e., they involved an authentic problem or scientific phenomenon), and coherent (i.e., the three dimensions are integrated in a meaningful way).


In the first design study, both groups of teachers received similar scores at baseline on the quality of their self-developed science assessment tasks. After taking part in the workshops or receiving the tools, both groups showed improvement; however the workshop group improved somewhat more, especially in their ability to connect the assessment items to a scenario. Results from the second design study also indicated that the assessment quality scores for both groups increased over time, but in this case the teachers who received tools showed slightly higher increases. It is important to note that the sample size was very small and the results are not necessarily generalizable. Taken together the studies suggest that the developed tools can be used to help teachers design three-dimensional assessments, with and without support.

The project produced several products related to three-dimensional assessment development that will be publicly and freely available online. Several science assessment development tools that have been vetted by experts are publicly available on the STEM Teaching Tools website (see Practice Briefs 26, 29, 30, 41). Resources from the face-to-face workshops including agendas and slides will be available on the Inquiry Hub website. Additionally, a conference paper describing the study and presenting initial results, along with the project’s rubric for assessing teacher-designed science assessment tasks are available on the Learn DBIR website.


The project team has plans to continue advancing this line of research and to create additional resources that support teachers’ learning about three-dimensional instruction and assessment. Towards the end of the performance award, the project team initiated development of an online course for science teachers, based on the activities and tools used in the design studies. Moreover, the research team recently received an NSF award (#2010086) to co-design, implement, and study the effectiveness of the online course with science teachers serving rural communities. Ultimately, by developing free or low-cost resources that support teacher learning, this project has the potential to broadly impact science teaching and learning across the United States.
